Hello-

Colin pointed out that the PDF I originally posted was not viewable=
 in
some software packages. I have updated the PDF. Please let me know if
y=
ou can't view it. Sorry about that.

Thanks Colin!


Best regards,
Jeff Clu=
ne

Postdoctoral Fellow
Hod Lipson's Computational Synthesis Laboratory
Cor=
nell University
jeffclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune



On Sun, Apr 24=
, 2011 at 3:29 AM, Jeff Clune <jeffclune@...> wrote:
> Hello all-
>=
 I am pleased to announce a paper by Marcin Suchorzewski and myself that
> =
describes a new generative encoding called the Developmental Symbolic
> Enc=
oding (DSE).
> DSE combines a key innovation from HyperNEAT (making phenoty=
pic properties a
> function of their geometric location) with an encoding i=
nspired by Cellular
> Encoding. =A0We investigate whether the types of neur=
al networks produced
> by=A0HyperNEAT are different from those produced by=
=A0DSE (an iterative,
> growth-based encoding). Specifically, we compare DS=
E to HyperNEAT with
> respect to each encoding's tendency to produce networ=
ks that are modular,
> regular, scale-free, and scalable. In general, we fi=
nd that DSE produced
> networks that were more modular and scale-free than =
HyperNEAT. We also found
> that DSE outperformed HyperNEAT on a pattern-rec=
ognition problem.
> I think you'll enjoy looking at the visualizations of t=
he networks evolved
> by DSE and HyperNEAT, and noting their differences. O=
verall, I think this
> work raises interesting questions as to what types o=
f encodings produce what
> types of network properties. For example, are it=
erative growth/rewrite
> encodings more likely to produce modular networks?=
 Does HyperNEAT need
> growth or recursion to increase its modularity? Etc.=
 What do you think?
> The DSE encoding is also an interesting and promising=
 encoding in its own
> right.
> Here is a link to the paper and the abstrac=
t:
> https://www.msu.edu/~jclune/webfiles/publications/2011-SuchorzewskiAnd=
Clune-DSE-Gecco.pdf
>
> A Novel Generative Encoding for Evolving Modular, R=
egular and Scalable
> Networks
>
> Suchorzewski M and Clune J. To appear in=
 the Proceedings of the Genetic and
> Evolutionary Computation Conference. =
=A02011.
>
> Abstract:=A0In this paper we introduce the Developmental Symbo=
lic Encoding
> (DSE), a new generative encoding for evolving networks (e.g.=
 neural or
> boolean). DSE combines elements of two powerful generative enc=
odings,
> Cellular Encoding and HyperNEAT, in order to evolve networks that=
 are
> modular, regular, scale-free, and scalable. Generating networks with=
 these
> properties is important because they can enhance performance and
>=
 evolvability. We test DSE=92s ability to generate scale-free and modular
>=
 networks by explicitly rewarding these properties and seeing whether
> evo=
lution can produce networks that possess them. We compare the networks
> DS=
E evolves to those of HyperNEAT. The results show that both encodings can
>=
 produce scale-free networks, although DSE performs slightly, but
> signifi=
cantly, better on this objective. DSE networks are far more modular
> than =
HyperNEAT networks. Both encodings produce regular networks. We further
> d=
emonstrate that individual DSE genomes during development can scale up a
> =
network pattern to accommodate different numbers of inputs. We also compare=

> DSE to HyperNEAT on a pattern recognition problem. DSE significantly
> o=
utperforms HyperNEAT, suggesting that its potential lay not just in the
> p=
roperties of the networks it produces, but also because it can compete with=

> leading encodings at solving challenging problems. These preliminary res=
ults
> imply that DSE is an interesting new encoding worthy of additional s=
tudy.
> The results also raise questions about which network properties are=
 more
> likely to be produced by different types of generative encodings.
>=

> PS.=A0Because there is not a current working distribution of Cellular
> =
Encoding, this encoding can serve as a descendent of CE if people wish to
>=
 compare against this type of encoding. We'd be happy to make the code
> av=
ailable.
> Best regards,
> Jeff Clune
>
> Postdoctoral Fellow
> Hod Lipson'=
s Creative Machines Laboratory
> Cornell University
> jeffclune@...=

> www.msu.edu/~jclune
